title: Old Man Hemlock's Lesson
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock had seen a thing or two in his ninety-odd years. He'd weathered storms both literal and figurative, seen empires rise and fall, and buried more friends than he cared to remember. Now, he mostly sat on his porch swing, whittling small wooden animals and watching the world go by. One crisp autumn afternoon, a young, ambitious lawyer named Ms. Davies, fresh out of law school, came to visit. She was determined to convince Old Man Hemlock to sell his land to a developer who wanted to build a sprawling golf course. 

Ms. Davies, armed with charts, graphs, and a contract thicker than a dictionary, launched into her pitch. She spoke of increased property values, economic opportunities, and the legacy he could leave behind. Old Man Hemlock listened patiently, whittling away at a small wooden squirrel. When she finally paused for breath, he simply looked at her and asked, "And what will become of the creek? The one that runs through the valley?" 

Ms. Davies, taken aback, stammered, "Well, I'm sure the developers have considered… drainage solutions…" Old Man Hemlock chuckled, a low, rumbling sound. "And the deer? The ones that drink from it every morning?" Ms. Davies’s face grew flushed. She reiterated the potential financial benefits, the prestige, the progress. Old Man Hemlock simply shook his head. "Progress, you say? I've seen a lot of progress, child. Most of it just leaves folks emptier than before." 

He held up the small wooden squirrel. "This little creature, made from a piece of fallen branch, reminds me to be humble. To appreciate what I have, not what I could get. To see the value in what already exists, not what I can build over it." Ms. Davies, defeated, finally gathered her papers and left. Old Man Hemlock watched her go, then returned to his whittling, a small smile playing on his lips. True wealth, he knew, wasn't found in progress or property, but in humility and gratitude for the simple blessings of life.
image_description: A weathered old man whittling a wooden animal on a porch, surrounded by autumn foliage.
insights: Old Man Hemlock's story reminds us that true humility is not about self-deprecation, but about a realistic assessment of our place in the world and a grateful acknowledgment of God's provision. Micah 6:8 asks, 'What does the Lord require of you but to do justice, and to love kindness, and to walk humbly with your God?' Walking humbly with God requires recognizing that all we have comes from Him (James 1:17) and that our worth is not tied to our accomplishments or possessions, but to our identity as His beloved children.
prayer: Heavenly Father, forgive me for the times I've chased after worldly success and forgotten to appreciate the simple blessings You've given me. Help me to cultivate a spirit of humility, recognizing that all I have comes from You. Grant me the wisdom to prioritize what truly matters – love, kindness, and walking humbly with You – over the pursuit of wealth and recognition. In Jesus’ name, Amen.
reflection: In what areas of your life are you tempted to prioritize ambition over humility? How can you cultivate a greater sense of gratitude for the simple blessings in your life? What small step can you take today to walk more humbly with God?
